unnormalised: India celebrates Diwali on 12/11/2023 this yr. The festival, also known as the Festival of Lights, typically falls b/w mid-October and mid-November, determined by the Hindu lunar calendar. Its date shifts yrly, but commonly occurs 21 days after Dussehra.
normalised: India celebrates Diwali on twelfth November two thousand and twenty three this year. The festival, also known as the Festival of Lights, typically falls between mid-October and mid-November, determined by the Hindu lunar calendar. Its date shifts yearly, but commonly occurs twenty one days after Dussehra.

unnormalised: Diwali spans 5 days, starting w/ Dhanteras on 09/11/23, followed by Naraka Chaturdashi (Choti Diwali) on 10/11/2023, Diwali itself on 12/11/23, Govardhan Puja on 13/11/2023, and finally Bhai Dooj on 14/11/2023. Each day holds distinct significance and rituals.
normalised: Diwali spans five days, starting with Dhanteras on ninth November two thousand and twenty three, followed by Naraka Chaturdashi (Choti Diwali) on tenth November two thousand and twenty three, Diwali itself on twelfth November two thousand and twenty three, Govardhan Puja on thirteenth November two thousand and twenty three, and finally Bhai Dooj on fourteenth November two thousand and twenty three. Each day holds distinct significance and rituals.

unnormalised: The positioning of Diwali is based on the lunisolar Hindu calendar, particularly the position of the moon. Diwali is celebrated on Amavasya, the new moon night, of the Kartik month. This is a dark nite; hence, the significance of lights & diyas.
normalised: The positioning of Diwali is based on the lunisolar Hindu calendar, particularly the position of the moon. Diwali is celebrated on Amavasya, the new moon night, of the Kartik month. This is a dark night; hence, the significance of lights and diyas.

unnormalised: Many ppl begin their preparations wks in adv., incl. cleaning & decorating their homes. It is a time when families come together, exchange gifts, and participate in traditional puja ceremonies. The fireworks commonly seen are a symbolic gesture of driving away darkness.
